Package edu.ncsu.csc.CoffeeMaker.services

Class Service<T extends DomainObject,​K>

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.ncsu.csc.CoffeeMaker.services.Service<T,​K>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - Type of entity that will be handled by this service
    K - Type of the key for this entity
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    IngredientService, InventoryService, RecipeService
    public abstract class Service<T extends DomainObject,​K>
extends java.lang.Object
    The Service class is responsible for providing CRUD operations against the database. It gives us a way to save objects, update them, retrieve the, or delete them. You should extend this class with your own Service for each persistent class (see the `models` package) that you create. Your new *Service can then be `Autowired` into the API controllers and tests that need it. Each Service class requires an appropriate *Repository instance (ie, UserService needs a UserRepository; IngredientService needs an IngredientRepository) with the `@Autowired` annotation on it. You'll also need to implement `getRepository()` to return this field.
    Author:
    Kai Presler-Marshall, Bruno Volpato da Cunha

    • Method Detail

      • save

        public void save​(T obj)
        Saves the provided object into the database. If the object already exists, `save()` will perform an in-place update, overwriting the existing record.
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to save into the database.

      • findAll

        public java.util.List<T> findAll()
        Returns all records of this type that exist in the database. If you want more precise ways of retrieving an individual record (or collection of records) see `findBy(Example)`
        Returns:
        All records stored in the database.

      • saveAll

        public void saveAll​(java.util.List<T> objects)
        Saves a collection of elements to the database. If an error occurs saving any of them, no objects will be saved. This makes it handy for ensuring database consistency where all records should exist together.
        Parameters:
        objects - A List of objects to save to the database.

      • delete

        public void delete​(T obj)
        Deletes an object from the database. This will remove the object from the database, but not from memory. Trying to save it again after deletion is undefined behaviour. YMMV.
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to delete from the database.

      • deleteAll

        public void deleteAll()
        Removes all records of a given type from the database. For example, `UserService.deleteAll()` would delete all Users. Be very careful when calling this.

      • count

        public long count()
        Returns a count of the number of records of a given type stored in the database. This is faster than, and should be preferred to, `findAll().size()` if you don't care about the actual records themselves.
        Returns:
        The number of records in the DB.

      • existsById

        public boolean existsById​(K id)
        Checks to see if an object with the provided ID exists or not
        Parameters:
        id - Id to check for existence of
        Returns:
        If the object was found

      • findById

        public T findById​(K id)
        Finds an object with the provided ID
        Parameters:
        id - ID of the object to find
        Returns:
        The found object, null if none
